title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: autograder supports two authentication modes:

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Uses public GitHub raw URLs without authentication. Test cases publicly accessible still protected : Hidden test cases (details shown students) Encrypted URL transmission Reference implementation obfuscation
code: # Check current mode (internal function) autograder:::.cpp_get_auth_info() #> $mode #> [1] "legacy" #> $has_token #> [1] FALSE

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Uses GitHub API personal access token private repository access: Test cases stored private repository Token embedded (encrypted) package Full repository access control
code: autograder:::.cpp_get_auth_info() #> $mode #> [1] "secure" #> $has_token #> [1] TRUE

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Create new private repository GitHub Add test case files:
code: private-repo/ ├── functions/ │   ├── _problems.R │   └── your_functions.R └── data/     └── your_data.csv

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Go GitHub → Settings → Developer Settings → Personal Access Tokens Click Generate new token (fine-grained) Name: autograder-course-name Expiration: End semester Repository access: select repositories → private repo Permissions: Contents → Read-Copy generated token

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Create .env file tools/ directory:
code: # tools/.env AUTH_MODE=secure REPO_URL=https://api.github.com/repos/YourOrg/PrivateRepo/contents GITHUB_TOKEN=github_pat_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
code: source("tools/encrypt_url_helper.R")  # Verify token works test_token() #> ✓ Token is valid #> ✓ Repository accessible #> ✓ Functions folder found  # Configure secure mode setup_secure_mode() #> ✓ Secure mode configured #> ✓ Token encrypted and embedded #> ✓ Package ready to build  # Build the package build_package()

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Distribute built package (.tar.gz .zip). Students install normally: token embedded encrypted—students don’t need configure anything.
code: install.packages("autograder_0.4.0.tar.gz", repos = NULL, type = "source") library(autograder) autograder("problem_name")

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Token encrypted using AES-256 derived key package build generates unique encryption Token never exposed plain text Students extract original token

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Use fine-grained tokens minimal permissions Set expiration dates aligned course Rotate tokens semester Scope specific repository Monitor repository access suspicious activity

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
code: library(autograder)  # Get authentication info (internal function) info <- autograder:::.cpp_get_auth_info() info$mode      # "legacy" or "secure" info$has_token # TRUE if token configured  # Get auth mode directly autograder:::.cpp_get_auth_mode() #> [1] "secure"

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: package exposes C++ functions authentication:
code: // In C++ extensions (internal) std::string mode = get_auth_mode();     // "legacy" or "secure" std::string token = get_github_token(); // encrypted token

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Solutions: - Verify token hasn’t expired - Check token Contents: Read permission - Confirm repository name correct - Ensure repository accessible token
code: Error: GitHub token validation failed

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Solutions: - Verify REPO_URL format: - API: https://api.github.com/repos/OWNER/REPO/contents - raw: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/OWNER/REPO/BRANCH/repo - Check repository exists accessible
code: Error: Repository not accessible

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
text: Solutions: - Ensure functions functions/ subfolder - Verify _problems.R lists function - Check file permissions repository
code: Error: Function 'problem_name' not found

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
code: source("tools/encrypt_url_helper.R") setup_legacy_mode() build_package()

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
code: source("tools/encrypt_url_helper.R")  # Create .env file first, then: setup_secure_mode() build_package()

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
code: # ============================================================================ # AUTOGRADER CONFIGURATION # ============================================================================  # Authentication mode: "secure" or "legacy" AUTH_MODE=secure  # Repository URL # Secure mode:  https://api.github.com/repos/OWNER/REPO/contents # Legacy mode:  https://raw.githubusercontent.com/OWNER/REPO/BRANCH/repo REPO_URL=https://api.github.com/repos/MyOrg/stat101-private/contents  # GitHub Personal Access Token (required for secure mode) GITHUB_TOKEN=github_pat_11ABCDEFG_xxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxxx  # Optional: Custom encryption key factors (comma-separated) # Leave empty to use defaults KEY_FACTORS=

title: Authentication and Private Repositories
code: # Get current authentication info info <- autograder:::.cpp_get_auth_info() # Returns: list with $mode and $has_token  # Get auth mode directly autograder:::.cpp_get_auth_mode() # Returns: "legacy" or "secure"

title: Working with Data Files
text: autograder supports external data files test cases. allows instructors create realistic data analysis problems students work CSV files, Excel spreadsheets, RDS objects, .

title: Working with Data Files
text: test case uses data files, autograder: Downloads data file instructor’s repository Loads using appropriate R function Passes loaded data function receive already-loaded data, file path!

what: Example: Writing a Data Analysis Function
title: Working with Data Files
code: # Your function receives a data frame directly student_analyze_scores <- function(data, statistic = "mean") {   # data is already loaded - don't use read.csv()!      # Find numeric columns   numeric_cols <- sapply(data, is.numeric)   numeric_data <- data[, numeric_cols, drop = FALSE]      # Calculate the requested statistic   switch(statistic,     "mean" = sapply(numeric_data, mean, na.rm = TRUE),     "median" = sapply(numeric_data, median, na.rm = TRUE),     "sum" = sapply(numeric_data, sum, na.rm = TRUE),     "count" = nrow(data)   ) }

title: Working with Data Files
code: # ❌ WRONG - Don't try to read the file yourself student_analyze <- function(data) {   df <- read.csv(data)  # data is already a data frame!   mean(df$value) }  # ✅ CORRECT - Use the data directly student_analyze <- function(data) {   mean(data$value) }

title: Working with Data Files
text: want test function locally sample data:
code: # Create sample data sample_data <- data.frame(   id = 1:10,   score = c(85, 92, 78, 95, 88, 72, 91, 84, 89, 76) )  # Test your function student_analyze_scores(sample_data, "mean")

title: Working with Data Files
text: Place data files data/ folder within repository:
code: your-repo/ ├── functions/ │   ├── _problems.R │   └── analyze_data.R └── data/     ├── sample_scores.csv     ├── measurements.rds     └── inventory.xlsx

title: Working with Data Files
code: # CSV scores <- data.frame(   student_id = 1:10,   score = sample(60:100, 10),   grade = sample(c("A", "B", "C"), 10, replace = TRUE) ) write.csv(scores, "data/sample_scores.csv", row.names = FALSE)  # RDS (any R object) model <- lm(mpg ~ wt, data = mtcars) saveRDS(model, "data/fitted_model.rds")  # RData (multiple objects) x <- 1:100 y <- x^2 save(x, y, file = "data/xy_data.RData")  # Excel library(openxlsx) write.xlsx(scores, "data/scores.xlsx")

title: Working with Data Files
text: Use data_files field declare required data files:
code: # functions/analyze_data.R  analyze_data <- function(data, type = "mean") {   numeric_cols <- sapply(data, is.numeric)   numeric_data <- data[, numeric_cols, drop = FALSE]      switch(type,     "mean" = sapply(numeric_data, mean),     "sum" = sapply(numeric_data, sum),     "count" = nrow(data)   ) }  test_cases <- list(   # Declare all data files needed   data_files = c("sample_scores.csv", "measurements.rds", "inventory.xlsx"),      inputs = list(     # String filename is replaced with loaded data at runtime     list(data = "sample_scores.csv", type = "mean"),     list(data = "measurements.rds", type = "sum"),     list(data = "inventory.xlsx", type = "count"),     # You can also use inline data     list(data = data.frame(x = 1:5, y = 6:10), type = "mean")   ),      descriptions = c(     "Calculate mean from CSV",     "Calculate sum from RDS",     "Count rows in Excel",     "Inline data test"   ),      points = c(2, 2, 2, 1),   hidden = c(FALSE, FALSE, TRUE, FALSE) )

title: Working with Data Files
text: test runs: Prefetching: files data_files downloaded cached Injection: input, value string matching data file, ’s replaced loaded data Execution: student function receives actual data
code: # What the student function sees: # Instead of: student_analyze(data = "sample_scores.csv") # It receives: student_analyze(data = <data.frame with scores>)

title: Working with Data Files
text: Data files cached shared across parallel workers efficiency:
code: # Cache is created once, shared with all workers autograder("analyze_data", use_parallel = TRUE)

title: Working with Data Files
text: Keep files small - Large files slow test execution Use descriptive names - student_grades_2024.csv data1.csv Document expected structure - Comments problem file Test data - Verify files load correctly

title: Working with Data Files
text: Mix data sources - Test different file types Include edge cases - Empty data, single row, missing values Hide sensitive tests - Use hidden = TRUE edge cases

title: Working with Data Files
code: # functions/summarize_sales.R  # Reference implementation summarize_sales <- function(sales_data, by = "product", metric = "total") {   if (nrow(sales_data) == 0) return(data.frame())      result <- aggregate(     sales_data$amount,     by = list(category = sales_data[[by]]),     FUN = switch(metric,       "total" = sum,       "average" = mean,       "count" = length     )   )   names(result) <- c(by, metric)   result }  test_cases <- list(   data_files = c("sales_2024.csv", "sales_empty.csv"),      inputs = list(     list(sales_data = "sales_2024.csv", by = "product", metric = "total"),     list(sales_data = "sales_2024.csv", by = "region", metric = "average"),     list(sales_data = "sales_empty.csv", by = "product", metric = "total")   ),      descriptions = c(     "Total sales by product",     "Average sales by region",     "Handle empty data"   ),      points = c(3, 3, 2),   hidden = c(FALSE, TRUE, TRUE),      hints = c(     "Use aggregate() to group and summarize",     "Make sure to handle different grouping columns",     "Return empty data frame for empty input"   ) )

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: autograder package provides automated testing framework R programming assignments. ’s designed help students learn providing immediate, detailed feedback code.

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: Install development version GitHub:
code: # install.packages("remotes") remotes::install_github("KingSSIBAL/R-Function-checker/autograder")

title: Getting Started with Autograder
code: library(autograder)

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: show functions can implement test:
code: list_problems() Available problems:    - fibonacci   - factorial   - sum_vector  Usage:   student_<function_name> <- function(...) { ... }   autograder('<function_name>')

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: implementing, see tests function needs pass: Output:
code: preview_tests("fibonacci") === Test Cases Preview ===  [Test 1] Base case: n = 1 (1 pt)   Input: list(1)  [Test 2] Small input: n = 5 (2 pt)   Input: list(5)  [Test 3] Medium input: n = 10 (2 pt)   Input: list(10)  ...

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: Create function prefix student_:
code: student_fibonacci <- function(n) {   if (n <= 0) return(numeric(0))   if (n == 1) return(1)      fib <- c(1, 1)   for (i in 3:n) {     fib[i] <- fib[i-1] + fib[i-2]   }   fib }

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: tests pass:
code: autograder("fibonacci") === Running Tests === [Test 1] Base case: n = 1 (1 pt): PASS [Test 2] Small input: n = 5 (2 pt): PASS [Test 3] Medium input: n = 10 (2 pt): PASS [Test 4] Larger input: n = 15 (3 pt): PASS [Test 5] (1 pt): PASS [Test 6] (1 pt): PASS  === Summary === Score: 10/10 points (100.0%) Tests: 6/6 passed (100.0%)  ✓ ALL TESTS PASSED! Excellent work!

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: test fails, autograder provides detailed feedback: Output:
code: # A buggy implementation student_fibonacci <- function(n) {   rep(0, n)  # Wrong! }  autograder("fibonacci") [Test 2] Small input: n = 5 (2 pt): FAIL   Input:    list(5)   Expected: c(1, 1, 2, 3, 5)   Got:      c(0, 0, 0, 0, 0)    Feedback:     * Differences at positions: 1, 2, 3, 4, 5

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: autograder() function several options:
code: autograder("fibonacci",    verbose = TRUE,       # Show detailed output (default: TRUE)   show_hidden = FALSE,  # Show hidden test details (default: FALSE)   show_progress = TRUE, # Show progress bar (default: FALSE)   use_parallel = TRUE,  # Use parallel execution (default: TRUE)   show_hints = TRUE     # Show hints for failures (default: TRUE) )

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: passing tests, can compare implementation’s performance reference solution: can also visualize comparison:
code: result <- compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 100) === Performance Comparison === Function: fibonacci Runs: 100 | Inputs: 4  ✓ Correctness: PASSED  Timing (seconds per batch):                     Student   Instructor   Median:          0.000150     0.000120   Mean:            0.000155     0.000125   ...  Performance Ratio: 1.25x (student/instructor) Verdict: SLOWER - Your implementation is somewhat slower. plot(result)

title: Getting Started with Autograder
text: Read Student Guide detailed usage See Instructor Guide ’re creating test cases Learn Data Files data analysis problems Understand Authentication private repositories Check Performance Benchmarking optimization tips

title: Instructor Guide
text: guide explains instructors can create manage programming assignments using autograder package. system allows : Create reference functions test cases Host problems GitHub easy distribution Track student performance point-weighted tests Include hidden tests comprehensive evaluation

title: Instructor Guide
text: Set GitHub repository structure:
code: your-course-repo/ ├── README.md └── functions/     ├── _problems.R          # Registry of available problems     ├── fibonacci.R          # Problem: fibonacci sequence     ├── factorial.R          # Problem: factorial function     └── sum_vector.R         # Problem: vector summation

title: Instructor Guide
text: Create functions/_problems.R list available problems: Students use list_problems() see list.
code: # functions/_problems.R # List of all available problems in this repository problems <- c(   "fibonacci",   "factorial",    "sum_vector",   "binary_search",   "matrix_multiply" )

title: Instructor Guide
text: problem file contains: 1. Reference function (instructor’s solution) 2. Test cases points descriptions 3. Optional hidden tests

title: Instructor Guide
code: # functions/fibonacci.R  # Reference function (instructor's solution) instructor_fibonacci <- function(n) {   if (n <= 0) return(integer(0))   if (n == 1) return(1L)   if (n == 2) return(c(1L, 1L))      fib <- integer(n)   fib[1:2] <- 1L   for (i in 3:n) {     fib[i] <- fib[i-1] + fib[i-2]   }   fib }  # Test cases test_cases <- list(   # Visible tests (students see inputs and expected outputs)   list(     description = "Edge case: n = 0 returns empty vector",     input = list(0),     points = 1   ),   list(     description = "Base case: n = 1",     input = list(1),     points = 1   ),   list(     description = "Base case: n = 2",      input = list(2),     points = 1   ),   list(     description = "Small sequence: n = 5",     input = list(5),     points = 2   ),   list(     description = "Medium sequence: n = 10",     input = list(10),     points = 2   ),      # Hidden tests (students don't see these)   list(     description = "Hidden: Large sequence",     input = list(20),     points = 3,     hidden = TRUE   ),   list(     description = "Hidden: Edge case handling",     input = list(-1),     points = 2,     hidden = TRUE   ) )

title: Instructor Guide
code: # Empty input list(description = "Empty vector", input = list(c()), points = 1)  # Single element list(description = "Single element", input = list(c(5)), points = 1)  # Zero/null values list(description = "Zero input", input = list(0), points = 1)

title: Instructor Guide
code: # Typical inputs list(description = "Small input", input = list(c(1, 2, 3)), points = 2) list(description = "Medium input", input = list(1:10), points = 2)

title: Instructor Guide
code: # Large inputs (often hidden) list(   description = "Large input performance",    input = list(1:1000),    points = 3,   hidden = TRUE )

title: Instructor Guide
code: # Different input types list(description = "Integer input", input = list(5L), points = 1) list(description = "Double input", input = list(5.0), points = 1) list(description = "Negative input", input = list(-5), points = 1)

title: Instructor Guide
text: functions multiple arguments:
code: # Reference function instructor_power <- function(base, exponent) {   base ^ exponent }  # Test cases test_cases <- list(   list(     description = "Simple power: 2^3",     input = list(2, 3),  # base = 2, exponent = 3     points = 1   ),   list(     description = "Negative exponent: 2^-1",     input = list(2, -1),  # base = 2, exponent = -1     points = 2   ),   list(     description = "Zero exponent: 5^0",     input = list(5, 0),     points = 1   ) )

title: Instructor Guide
text: Recommended point distribution: Example 20-point problem:
code: test_cases <- list(   # Edge cases (4 points)   list(description = "Empty input", input = list(c()), points = 2),   list(description = "Single element", input = list(c(1)), points = 2),      # Basic functionality (8 points)   list(description = "Small array", input = list(1:5), points = 2),   list(description = "Medium array", input = list(1:10), points = 3),   list(description = "Negative numbers", input = list(-5:-1), points = 3),      # Advanced (5 points)   list(description = "Mixed values", input = list(c(-2, 0, 2)), points = 2),   list(description = "Duplicates", input = list(c(1, 1, 2, 2)), points = 3),      # Hidden (3 points)   list(description = "Large input", input = list(1:1000), points = 3, hidden = TRUE) )

title: Instructor Guide
text: Create public GitHub repository (e.g., stat101-assignments).

title: Instructor Guide
text: Push problem files repository.

title: Instructor Guide
text: Students point autograder repository:
code: library(autograder)  # Set your course repository options(autograder_repo = "username/stat101-assignments")  # Now students can list and test problems list_problems() autograder("fibonacci")

title: Instructor Guide
text: default base URL : can customize package configuration.
code: https://raw.githubusercontent.com/{repo}/main/functions/

title: Instructor Guide
text: maximum security, use private repository token authentication: Create private GitHub repository Generate fine-grained personal access token Configure secure mode (see Authentication Guide)

title: Instructor Guide
text: Hidden tests protect grading criteria: Students see: [Test 6] Hidden test (5 pts): PASS/FAIL actual input expected output.
code: list(   description = "Hidden: Stress test",   input = list(1:10000),   points = 5,   hidden = TRUE )

title: Instructor Guide
text: autograder encrypts function code transit using RSA encryption. Reference implementations protected direct inspection.

title: Instructor Guide
text: Use hidden tests edge cases don’t want revealed Rotate problems semester prevent sharing Include unique test values hard guess Monitor suspicious patterns submissions Use private repositories exams (see Authentication)

title: Instructor Guide
text: problems requiring external data (CSV, Excel, RDS), see Data Files Guide. Quick example:
code: test_cases <- list(   # Declare data files   data_files = c("scores.csv", "inventory.xlsx"),      inputs = list(     # Filename is replaced with loaded data     list(data = "scores.csv", type = "mean"),     list(data = "inventory.xlsx", type = "sum")   ),      descriptions = c("CSV analysis", "Excel analysis"),   points = c(2, 2) )

title: Instructor Guide
text: Check : 1. problem listed _problems.R 2. filename matches (e.g., fibonacci.R “fibonacci”) 3. repository accessible

title: Instructor Guide
text: Ensure test case : - description (string) - input (list) - points (positive integer)

title: Instructor Guide
text: Check: - Repository public - GitHub accessible - Base URL correct

title: Instructor Guide
code: # functions/mean_absolute_deviation.R  # Reference function instructor_mean_absolute_deviation <- function(x) {   if (length(x) == 0) return(NA_real_)   mean(abs(x - mean(x))) }  # Test cases test_cases <- list(   # Edge cases   list(     description = "Empty vector returns NA",     input = list(c()),     points = 2   ),   list(     description = "Single element returns 0",     input = list(c(5)),     points = 2   ),      # Basic functionality   list(     description = "Simple case: c(1, 2, 3)",     input = list(c(1, 2, 3)),     points = 3   ),   list(     description = "Larger range: 1:10",     input = list(1:10),     points = 3   ),      # Advanced cases   list(     description = "Negative values",     input = list(c(-3, -1, 0, 1, 3)),     points = 3   ),   list(     description = "Floating point values",     input = list(c(1.5, 2.5, 3.5)),     points = 2   ),      # Hidden tests   list(     description = "Hidden: Large vector",     input = list(rnorm(1000)),     points = 3,     hidden = TRUE   ),   list(     description = "Hidden: All same values",     input = list(rep(5, 100)),     points = 2,     hidden = TRUE   ) )

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: autograder includes performance benchmarking features compare implementation’s speed instructor’s reference solution. helps learn write efficient code.

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: function passes tests, use compare_performance() benchmark:
code: library(autograder)  # First, ensure your function passes all tests result <- autograder("fibonacci")  # Then benchmark performance perf <- compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 100)

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: function returns performance comparison object components:
code: perf$student_median   # Median execution time for your function perf$instructor_median # Median execution time for reference perf$student_mean     # Mean execution time for your function perf$instructor_mean  # Mean execution time for reference perf$ratio            # How many times slower/faster you are perf$n_runs           # Number of benchmark iterations

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: ratio < 1: code faster reference ratio = 1: performance ratio > 1: code slower reference Example output:
code: Performance Comparison for 'fibonacci' ======================================                     Student    Instructor Median time:        0.015ms    0.012ms Mean time:          0.018ms    0.014ms Std deviation:      0.005ms    0.003ms  Performance ratio: 1.25x (student/instructor) Your implementation is 25% slower than the reference.  Based on 100 runs per implementation.

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: Use plot method visual comparison: creates side--side boxplot showing distribution execution times implementations.
code: plot(perf)

previous_headings: Optimizing Your Code > Common Performance Issues
title: Performance Benchmarking
text: Bad (slow): Good (fast):
code: # Growing a vector in a loop is O(n²) result <- c() for (i in 1:n) {   result <- c(result, compute(i)) } # Pre-allocate the vector - O(n) result <- numeric(n) for (i in 1:n) {   result[i] <- compute(i) }

previous_headings: Optimizing Your Code > Common Performance Issues
title: Performance Benchmarking
text: Bad (slow): Good (fast):
code: # Calculating mean inside loop for (i in 1:n) {   deviation[i] <- x[i] - mean(x)  # mean(x) calculated n times! } # Calculate once, use many times m <- mean(x) for (i in 1:n) {   deviation[i] <- x[i] - m }

previous_headings: Optimizing Your Code > Common Performance Issues
title: Performance Benchmarking
text: Bad (slow): Good (fast):
code: # Loop-based sum total <- 0 for (i in 1:length(x)) {   total <- total + x[i] } # Vectorized total <- sum(x)

previous_headings: Optimizing Your Code > Common Performance Issues
title: Performance Benchmarking
text: Bad (slow): Good (fast):
code: # Naive recursive Fibonacci - O(2^n) fib <- function(n) {   if (n <= 2) return(1)   fib(n-1) + fib(n-2) } # Iterative Fibonacci - O(n) fib <- function(n) {   if (n <= 0) return(integer(0))   if (n == 1) return(1L)      result <- integer(n)   result[1:2] <- 1L   for (i in 3:n) {     result[i] <- result[i-1] + result[i-2]   }   result }

title: Performance Benchmarking
code: # Instead of manual implementation x_sorted <- x[order(x)]  # Use built-in sort (implemented in C) x_sorted <- sort(x)

title: Performance Benchmarking
code: # Instead of loop squares <- numeric(length(x)) for (i in seq_along(x)) {   squares[i] <- x[i]^2 }  # Use vectorization squares <- x^2

title: Performance Benchmarking
code: # Instead of loop over rows for (i in 1:nrow(mat)) {   row_sums[i] <- sum(mat[i, ]) }  # Use apply row_sums <- apply(mat, 1, sum)  # Even better: use rowSums row_sums <- rowSums(mat)

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: runs give reliable results:
code: # Quick check compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 10)  # Reliable benchmark compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 1000)

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: autograder uses last test case default. comprehensive benchmarking, consider input sizes function typically handle.

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: High standard deviation indicates inconsistent performance: might indicate: - Memory allocation overhead - Garbage collection interference - System background processes
code: Std deviation:  0.500ms  (high variability)

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: Run benchmark several times ensure consistency:
code: for (i in 1:3) {   print(compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 100)) }

title: Performance Benchmarking
text: Performance optimization important : Processing large datasets - O(n²) vs O(n) makes huge difference Called frequently - Functions tight loops fast Real-time applications - Latency-sensitive code Competition/grading - assignments grade efficiency Performance optimization less important : Correctness stake - Always prefer correct fast One-time operations - Setup code runs Small inputs - Optimization overhead may exceed savings Code readability - Maintainable code often better micro-optimized code

title: Performance Benchmarking
code: library(autograder)  # 1. Check available problems list_problems()  # 2. Preview test cases preview_tests("fibonacci")  # 3. Create your function student_fibonacci <- function(n) {   if (n <= 0) return(integer(0))   if (n == 1) return(1L)      fib <- integer(n)   fib[1:2] <- 1L   for (i in 3:n) {     fib[i] <- fib[i-1] + fib[i-2]   }   fib }  # 4. Test for correctness result <- autograder("fibonacci") print(result)  # 5. If all tests pass, benchmark performance if (result$pass_rate == 100) {   perf <- compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 100)   print(perf)   plot(perf) }

title: Student Guide
text: guide explains use autograder package test R programming assignments. autograder provides immediate feedback code, helping learn improve.

title: Student Guide
text: Discover available problems list_problems() Preview test cases preview_tests("function_name") Implement solution student_function_name Test autograder("function_name") Iterate based feedback tests pass Optimize (optional) using compare_performance()

title: Student Guide
text: shows functions available testing course.
code: library(autograder) list_problems()

title: Student Guide
text: writing code, understand ’s expected: shows: - Test descriptions - test checks - Input values - arguments passed - Point values - much test worth - Hidden tests - Existence noted, details hidden
code: preview_tests("fibonacci")

title: Student Guide
text: Name function student_ prefix:
code: # For the "fibonacci" problem, create student_fibonacci student_fibonacci <- function(n) {   # Your implementation here }

title: Student Guide
text: autograder returns results object:
code: result <- autograder("fibonacci") result$passed     # Number of tests passed result$failed     # Number of tests failed result$total      # Total tests result$score      # Points earned result$max_score  # Maximum points result$pass_rate  # Percentage passed

title: Student Guide
code: [Test 1] Base case: n = 1 (1 pt): PASS

title: Student Guide
code: [Test 2] Small input: n = 5 (2 pt): FAIL   Input:    list(5)   Expected: c(1, 1, 2, 3, 5)   Got:      c(1, 1, 2, 3, 4)    Feedback:     * Differences at positions: 5

title: Student Guide
code: [Test 1] Base case (1 pt): FAIL (Type Error)   Expected type: numeric   Got type: character

title: Student Guide
code: [Test 1] Base case (1 pt): FAIL (Error)   Input: list(5)   Error: object 'x' not found

title: Student Guide
text: Use feedback fix code:
code: # Test your function manually with the failing input student_fibonacci(5) # Compare with expected output # Fix the bug # Run autograder again autograder("fibonacci")

title: Student Guide
text: Test function manually running autograder:
code: # Test edge cases first student_fibonacci(0) student_fibonacci(1) student_fibonacci(2)  # Then larger inputs student_fibonacci(10)

title: Student Guide
text: autograder provides specific feedback: - Position differences tell exactly output differs - Type errors indicate wrong return type - Runtime errors show R error messages function

title: Student Guide
text: Many problems edge cases: - Empty input (n = 0) - Single element (n = 1) - Negative numbers - large inputs

title: Student Guide
text: Get detailed output debugging:
code: autograder("fibonacci", verbose = TRUE, show_hints = TRUE)

title: Student Guide
text: Common type issues:
code: # Wrong: returning string instead of number return("5")  # Right: returning number return(5)  # Wrong: returning list instead of vector return(list(1, 2, 3))  # Right: returning vector return(c(1, 2, 3))

title: Student Guide
text: Solution: Make sure function named correctly student_ prefix.
code: Error: Function 'student_fibonacci' not found in your environment.

title: Student Guide
text: Solution: Check ’re returning numbers, strings.
code: Type mismatch: Expected numeric but got character

title: Student Guide
text: Solution: Check loop bounds --one errors.
code: Length mismatch: Expected length 10 but got 9

title: Student Guide
text: Solution: autograder needs internet fetch test cases. Check connection.
code: No internet connection detected.

title: Student Guide
text: problems require function analyze data files (CSV, Excel, RDS). autograder handles data loading automatically!

title: Student Guide
text: test uses data files: 1. autograder downloads data file 2. Loads R (data frame, list, etc.) 3. Passes loaded data function function receives data directly, file path!

title: Student Guide
text: details, see Working Data Files.
code: # ✅ CORRECT - data is already a data frame student_analyze <- function(data, stat = "mean") {   sapply(data[sapply(data, is.numeric)],           switch(stat, mean = mean, sum = sum)) }  # ❌ WRONG - don't try to read the file student_analyze <- function(data, stat = "mean") {   df <- read.csv(data)  # data is NOT a filename!   # ... }

title: Student Guide
text: passing tests, optimize code: shows implementation compares reference solution terms speed.
code: result <- compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 100) print(result) plot(result)

title: Student Guide
text: ’re stuck: 1. Re-read test case descriptions preview_tests() 2. Test function manually simple inputs 3. Check function requirements/documentation 4. Ask instructor help

title: Authors and Citation
text: Agub Reijel. Author, maintainer.

title: Authors and Citation
text: Reijel (2025). autograder: Automated R Function Testing Grading C++ Backend. R package version 0.4.0, https://kingsibal.github.io/R-Function-checker/.
code: @Manual{,   title = {autograder: Automated R Function Testing and Grading with C++ Backend},   author = {Agub Reijel},   year = {2025},   note = {R package version 0.4.0},   url = {https://kingsibal.github.io/R-Function-checker/}, }

what: Run autograder by function name — autograder
title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
text: Tests student implementation reference outputs support points, descriptions, hidden tests, type checking, tolerance, parallel execution, detailed feedback. main function students use test work.

title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
code: autograder(   function_name,   verbose = TRUE,   show_hidden = FALSE,   show_progress = FALSE,   use_parallel = TRUE,   show_hints = TRUE )

title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
text: function_name Character. Name function test. Must match function repository (see list_problems()). Example: "fibonacci", "factorial", "sum_vector" verbose Logical. Show detailed output test? TRUE (default): Shows inputs, expected, actual output failures FALSE: Shows test result (PASS/FAIL) summary show_hidden Logical. Show details hidden tests? FALSE (default): Hidden tests show PASS/FAIL TRUE: Hidden tests show full details (instructor review) show_progress Logical. Show progress bar many tests? FALSE (default): progress bar TRUE: Shows progress bar ≥6 tests use_parallel Logical. Use parallel processing? TRUE (default): Automatic parallel ≥10 tests FALSE: Always use sequential execution show_hints Logical. Show hints failed tests? TRUE (default): Display instructor hints available FALSE: Hide hints (exams/assessments)

title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
text: Invisibly returns list test results: passed: Integer. Number tests passed failed: Integer. Number tests failed total: Integer. Total number tests score: Numeric. Points earned max_score: Numeric. Maximum possible points pass_rate: Numeric. Percentage tests passed (0-100)

title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
text: See available problems: list_problems() Preview test cases: preview_tests("function_name") Define function: student_function_name <- function(...) { ... } Run autograder: autograder("function_name") Review feedback improve code Repeat tests pass

title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
text: Sequential mode: ~100-500ms per test (depends function complexity) Parallel mode: ~50-200ms per test 4-core system Network fetch: ~1-3 seconds (cached OS first call)

title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
text: function provides specific, actionable error messages: "Function found" → Use list_problems() "Type mismatch" → Check return type "Length mismatch" → Check loop bounds edge cases "Network error" → Check internet connection

title: Run autograder by function name — autograder
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # 1. Define your solution student_fibonacci <- function(n) {   if (n <= 0) return(numeric(0))   if (n == 1) return(1)   fib <- c(1, 1)   for (i in 3:n) {     fib[i] <- fib[i-1] + fib[i-2]   }   fib }  # 2. Run autograder result <- autograder("fibonacci")  # 3. Check your score print(result$pass_rate)  # 100 if all passed  # 4. Run with different options autograder("fibonacci", verbose = FALSE)           # Minimal output autograder("fibonacci", show_hints = TRUE)         # Show hints autograder("fibonacci", use_parallel = FALSE)      # Force sequential } # }

what: Compare Performance of Student vs Instructor Implementation — compare_performance
title: Compare Performance of Student vs Instructor Implementation — compare_performance
text: Benchmarks student's function implementation instructor's reference solution evaluate computational efficiency. function measures: Execution time (median, mean, min, max) Relative performance (student vs instructor ratio) Consistency (standard deviation)

title: Compare Performance of Student vs Instructor Implementation — compare_performance
code: compare_performance(   function_name,   n_runs = 100L,   warmup = 5L,   test_inputs = NULL,   verbose = TRUE )

title: Compare Performance of Student vs Instructor Implementation — compare_performance
text: function_name Character string. Name problem/function benchmark. n_runs Integer. Number benchmark iterations (default: 100). warmup Integer. Number warmup runs timing (default: 5). test_inputs List. Custom test inputs benchmarking. NULL, uses test cases problem definition. verbose Logical. Whether print detailed output (default: TRUE).

title: Compare Performance of Student vs Instructor Implementation — compare_performance
text: list class "performance_comparison" containing: function_name function tested n_runs Number benchmark iterations student_times Vector student execution times (seconds) instructor_times Vector instructor execution times (seconds) student_stats Summary statistics student (median, mean, sd, min, max) instructor_stats Summary statistics instructor ratio Performance ratio (student/instructor, >1 means slower) passed_correctness Whether student output matches instructor verdict Human-readable performance assessment

title: Compare Performance of Student vs Instructor Implementation — compare_performance
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Define student function student_fibonacci <- function(n) {   if (n <= 0) return(numeric(0))   if (n == 1) return(1)   fib <- c(1, 1)   for (i in 3:n) fib[i] <- fib[i-1] + fib[i-2]   fib }  # Run performance comparison result <- compare_performance("fibonacci")  # Custom number of runs result <- compare_performance("fibonacci", n_runs = 500)  # Custom test inputs result <- compare_performance("fibonacci",    test_inputs = list(list(20), list(30), list(50))) } # }

what: Fetch a data file from the repository — fetch_data
title: Fetch a data file from the repository — fetch_data
text: Downloads data file repository's data/ folder loads R. Supported Formats: CSV: Loaded read.csv() data.frame RDS: Loaded readRDS() (R object) RData/rda: Loaded load() environment TXT: Loaded readLines() character vector XLSX/XLS: Loaded readxl::read_excel() tibble/data.frame Security: Filename validated C++ (path traversal) allowed extensions: csv, rds, rda, RData, txt, xlsx, xls Downloaded temporary file (cleaned R)

what: Securely fetch and load instructor code from repository — fetch_instructor_code
title: Securely fetch and load instructor code from repository — fetch_instructor_code
text: Downloads instructor's reference implementation test cases GitHub repository comprehensive error handling. Security Measures: Input validation via C++ (prevents path traversal) HTTPS transport (encrypted transit) Error message sanitization (path exposure) Timeout handling (30 seconds)

title: Securely fetch and load instructor code from repository — fetch_instructor_code
code: fetch_instructor_code(function_name)

title: Securely fetch and load instructor code from repository — fetch_instructor_code
text: function_name Name function fetch (validated C++)

title: Securely fetch and load instructor code from repository — fetch_instructor_code
text: Environment containing: Instructor's function implementation test_cases list test data

title: Securely fetch and load instructor code from repository — fetch_instructor_code
text: Workflow: Call C++ function download code Create new isolated environment Parse evaluate code environment Return environment extraction Error Handling: Invalid name → InvalidInputError Network issue → network_error 404 error → function_not_found_error → generic error

title: Securely fetch and load instructor code from repository — fetch_instructor_code
text: Creates temporary file (automatically cleaned R)

what: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
title: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
text: Formats R objects display type-aware strategies prevent overwhelming output preserving essential information. Design Goals: Show enough information understand object Prevent screen overflow large objects Preserve structure small objects Handle common R types gracefully

title: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
code: format_output(obj, max_length = 200, preserve_structure = TRUE)

title: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
text: obj R object format (type) max_length Maximum characters output (default: 200) preserve_structure Keep full structure lists? (default: TRUE)

title: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
text: Character string representation, never exceeds max_length + 3

title: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
text: Formatting Strategy Type: NULL: Returns: "NULL" Lists (small, ≤3 elements): Shows: Full structure Example: list(= 1, b = 2, c = 3) Lists (large, >3 elements): Shows: list(length=100, first 3: ..., ...) Vectors (≤10 elements): Shows: Full deparsed representation Example: c(1, 2, 3, 4, 5) Vectors (>10 elements): Shows: type[1:n] = first, second, third ... type[n] = last Example: integer[1:100] = 1, 2, 3 ... integer[100] = 100 Matrices: Shows: matrix[rows x cols]: first_values ... Example: matrix[3x4]: 1 2 3 ... Data Frames: Shows: data.frame[rows x cols] columns: col1, col2, col3 Example: data.frame[10 x 3] columns: x, y, z

title: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
text: Time: O(1) types (uses head/tail) Space: O(k) k = min(object_size, max_length)

title: Intelligent output formatting with smart truncation — format_output
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Small vector - full output format_output(1:5) # "1:5"  # Large vector - truncated format_output(1:1000) # "integer[1:1000] = 1, 2, 3 ... integer[1000] = 1000"  # Data frame - summary format_output(mtcars) # "data.frame[32 x 11] columns: mpg, cyl, disp, hp, ..."  # Matrix - dimensions format_output(matrix(1:100, 10, 10)) # "matrix[10x10]: 1 2 3 ..." } # }

title: List available problems/functions to test — list_problems

title: Custom error for network-related issues — network_error
text: Common network issues error represents: internet connection Server unreachable Timeout (>30 seconds) DNS resolution failure Firewall blocking connection

title: Custom error for network-related issues — network_error
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ if (!curl::has_internet()) {   stop(network_error("No internet connection detected")) } } # }

what: Preview test cases without running them — preview_tests
title: Preview test cases without running them — preview_tests
text: Shows test case inputs, descriptions, point values without executing code. Hidden tests show summary information maintain assessment integrity. Use Case: Students can review test cases understand requirements implementing solution.

title: Preview test cases without running them — preview_tests
code: preview_tests(function_name)

title: Preview test cases without running them — preview_tests
text: function_name Character. Name function preview.

title: Preview test cases without running them — preview_tests
text: Invisibly returns test_data structure (programmatic access)

title: Preview test cases without running them — preview_tests
code: === Test Cases Preview ===  [Test 1] Base case: n = 1 (1 pt)   Input: list(1)  [Test 2] Small input: n = 5 (2 pt)   Input: list(5)  [Test 3] [HIDDEN TEST] (2 pt)  === Summary === Total tests: 3 Visible tests: 2 Hidden tests: 1 Total points: 5

title: Preview test cases without running them — preview_tests
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # See what tests exist for fibonacci preview_tests("fibonacci")  # Capture test data for analysis test_data <- preview_tests("fibonacci") print(test_data$points)  # See point distribution } # }

title: Display feedback messages in formatted style — print_feedback
text: Prints feedback list clean, readable format bullet points.

code: print_feedback(feedback)

title: Display feedback messages in formatted style — print_feedback
text: feedback Named list feedback messages provide_feedback()

title: Display feedback messages in formatted style — print_feedback
text: NULL (invisible), called side effect printing

title: Display feedback messages in formatted style — print_feedback
text: Output Format: Feedback: * Type mismatch: Expected numeric got character * Hint: Check return type Handles empty feedback gracefully (prints nothing).

what: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
title: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
text: Compares student output expected output generates specific, actionable feedback help students understand mistakes. Analysis Categories: Type Analysis: Checks output type matches expectation Common student errors: Returning character "5" instead numeric 5 Returning list instead vector Returning data.frame instead matrix Dimension Analysis: vectors: checks length Common student errors: --one errors (length 9 instead 10) handling edge cases (empty input) Starting wrong index Value Analysis: numeric vectors: identifies positions differ Common student errors: Logic errors loop Wrong formula Incorrect initial values Hint Integration: Adds instructor-provided hints available

title: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
code: provide_feedback(student_out, expected_out, input_args, hint = NULL)

title: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
text: student_out Student's function output expected_out Expected (correct) output input_args Input arguments used test hint Optional instructor hint (NULL character string)

title: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
text: Named list feedback messages, may empty outputs match

title: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
text: Return Structure: list( type_issue = "Type mismatch: ...",      # types differ length_issue = "Length mismatch: ...",  # lengths differ diff_positions = "Differences ...",   # values differ hint = "Hint: ..."                      # hint provided )

title: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
text: Time: O(n) vectors, O(1) type/length checks Space: O(k) k = number feedback messages (typically 1-3)

title: Analyze differences and generate helpful feedback — provide_feedback
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Type mismatch provide_feedback("5", 5, list(x = 5)) # Returns: list(type_issue = "Type mismatch: Expected numeric but got character")  # Length mismatch provide_feedback(1:5, 1:10, list(n = 10)) # Returns: list(length_issue = "Length mismatch: Expected length 10 but got 5")  # Value differences provide_feedback(c(1, 5, 3), c(1, 2, 3), list()) # Returns: list(diff_positions = "Differences at positions: 2")  # With hint provide_feedback(5, 10, list(x = 2), "Try multiplying by 2") # Returns: list(hint = "Hint: Try multiplying by 2") } # }

what: Run tests in parallel using multiple CPU cores — run_tests_parallel
title: Run tests in parallel using multiple CPU cores — run_tests_parallel
text: Executes test cases parallel improved performance multi-core systems. Automatically falls back sequential small test sets. Parallel Execution Strategy: Create cluster n cores (leave 1 free system) Export student_fun, instructor_fun, tolerance workers Distribute test indices across workers worker: runs test, catches errors, returns result Main process: collects results, cleans cluster

title: Run tests in parallel using multiple CPU cores — run_tests_parallel
code: run_tests_parallel(   student_fun,   instructor_fun,   test_data,   tolerance,   use_parallel = TRUE,   data_cache = list() )

title: Run tests in parallel using multiple CPU cores — run_tests_parallel
text: student_fun Student's function implementation instructor_fun Instructor's reference implementation test_data Validated test case data tolerance Numeric tolerance comparisons use_parallel Whether actually use parallel (TRUE) fall back (FALSE) data_cache Named list loaded data objects (optional)

title: Run tests in parallel using multiple CPU cores — run_tests_parallel
text: List test results, containing: student: student output error object expected: expected output error object index: test number (1-based)

title: Run tests in parallel using multiple CPU cores — run_tests_parallel
text: Performance Characteristics: Setup cost: ~100-200ms (cluster creation) Per-test overhead: ~10ms (serialization) Speedup: typically 2-4x 4-core system Worth : ≥10 tests Core Allocation Strategy: Detect available cores Use cores - 1 (keep system responsive) Cap 4 cores (diminishing returns beyond ) Example: 8-core system → use 4 cores

title: Run tests in parallel using multiple CPU cores — run_tests_parallel
text: Cluster always stopped via .exit(), even errors occur. prevents orphaned R processes.

what: Run tests sequentially (one after another) — run_tests_sequential
title: Run tests sequentially (one after another) — run_tests_sequential
text: Executes test cases one time order. Used : Small test sets (<10 tests) use_parallel = FALSE Debugging (easier trace) Advantages Parallel: setup overhead Easier debugging (linear execution) predictable Better small test sets

title: Run tests sequentially (one after another) — run_tests_sequential
code: run_tests_sequential(   student_fun,   instructor_fun,   test_data,   tolerance,   data_cache = list() )

title: Run tests sequentially (one after another) — run_tests_sequential
text: student_fun Student's function instructor_fun Instructor's reference function test_data Validated test case data tolerance Numeric tolerance data_cache Named list loaded data objects (optional)

title: Run tests sequentially (one after another) — run_tests_sequential
text: List test results (structure parallel version)

title: Run tests sequentially (one after another) — run_tests_sequential
text: Execution Flow: test: 1. Extract input arguments 2. Inject data needed 3. Call student function (catch errors) 4. Call instructor function (catch errors) 5. Package results 6. Move next test Error Handling: Errors captured, thrown. allows: tests run (one failure stop others) Detailed error reporting test Graceful handling student code errors

title: Custom error for test execution failures — test_execution_error
code: test_execution_error(message, test_number, call = NULL)

title: Custom error for test execution failures — test_execution_error
text: message Description went wrong test_number test failed (1-based index) call call generated error

title: Custom error for test execution failures — test_execution_error
text: S3 object class c("test_execution_error", "error", "condition")

title: Custom error for test execution failures — test_execution_error
text: Used : Test setup fails Input arguments invalid Unexpected runtime error test harness

what: Validate and normalize test case structure — validate_test_cases
title: Validate and normalize test case structure — validate_test_cases
text: Performs comprehensive validation test case data structure strict error checking. Ensures test components properly formatted consistent. Required Fields: inputs: list input argument lists (REQUIRED) Optional Fields (defaults): descriptions: character vector test descriptions hidden: logical vector indicating hidden tests points: numeric vector point values per test tolerance: single numeric floating-point comparison expected_type: single character specifying expected output type hints: character vector hints failed tests comparison_fn: custom comparison function

title: Validate and normalize test case structure — validate_test_cases
code: validate_test_cases(test_data, function_name)

title: Validate and normalize test case structure — validate_test_cases
text: test_data List containing test case configuration function_name Name function (error messages)

title: Validate and normalize test case structure — validate_test_cases
text: Validated normalized test_data fields present

title: Validate and normalize test case structure — validate_test_cases
text: Validation Strategy: Critical Fields (STOP error): Missing inputs: Hard error (proceed) Mismatched lengths: Hard error (data corruption) Invalid types: Hard error (wrong configuration) Optional Fields (WARN fix): Missing: Fill defaults Wrong format: Warn ignore Can proceed: Yes Error Messages: Clear indication wrong Tells user contact instructor (config issue) Never blames student instructor errors

title: Validate and normalize test case structure — validate_test_cases
code: if (FALSE) { # \dontrun{ # Valid test case test_data <- list(   inputs = list(list(1), list(2)),   descriptions = c("Test 1", "Test 2"),   points = c(1, 2) ) validated <- validate_test_cases(test_data, "my_function")  # Missing optional fields - filled with defaults test_data_minimal <- list(   inputs = list(list(1)) ) validated <- validate_test_cases(test_data_minimal, "my_function") # Returns: descriptions = "Test 1", hidden = FALSE, points = 1, tolerance = 1e-10 } # }

title: autograder 0.4.0
text: Complete modular refactoring R codebase 11 separate files better maintainability C++ backend split modular components (executor, comparer, hasher, encryption) Improved parallel test execution better error handling Added dual authentication modes: legacy (public) secure (private repositories) Added data file support test cases (CSV, Excel, RDS, RData, TXT)

title: autograder 0.4.0
text: Added compare_performance() benchmarking student vs instructor implementations Added preview_tests() let students see test cases coding Added list_problems() discover available problems Added encryption utilities: encrypt_text(), decrypt_text(), generate_key(), derive_key() Added comprehensive pkgdown documentation site Added fetch_data() loading external data files test cases Added prefetch_data_files() efficient data caching Added inject_data_into_inputs() automatic data injection Added .cpp_get_auth_info() .cpp_get_auth_mode() authentication status Added GitHub token authentication private repository access Added Excel file support (.xlsx, .xls) via readxl package

title: autograder 0.4.0
text: Test coverage improved 55%+ 2015 unit tests Added vignettes students, instructors, data files, authentication, performance Improved error messages feedback formatting Data files cached shared across parallel workers

title: autograder 0.3.0
text: Added parallel test execution support via run_tests_parallel() Implemented C++ backend performance-critical operations Added RSA encryption secure code transmission

title: autograder 0.3.0
text: Fixed edge case handling empty test suites Improved network error messages

title: autograder 0.2.0
text: Added hidden test support Added point-weighted test cases Improved feedback formatting detailed diff output

title: autograder 0.1.0
text: Initial release Basic autograder functionality GitHub-based test case fetching Support single-function testing
